Two servers used different RSA keys but accidentally shared a prime. Both public keys and 4513339231365692865315568951468188206127397826601101069365770689117710438716177838633016449906100919715610506998744776461974845935890298250600036819908013 were intercepted. Can you recover the original message?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=4712401139916324197463577994409472335085326807548200171055544356374466169605754904431374927687932844845336303429759309028438846925997725007196670418275803, n2=7021751681354724785338252981968342029515080817018229161722818294944812859596860289421556580058638563852865392178753470870968499636104957750005714982251017, e=1155464652474737721100294710982594581740744116817794578290784982155087295633066402205873278963008261401489285095665238900365716523807483281719184262257123

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{imdygjoz}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 4513339231365692865315568951468188206127397826601101069365770689117710438716177838633016449906100919715610506998744776461974845935890298250600036819908013
vulnerability: shared prime
hint: When two RSA moduli share a common prime, computing GCD(n, n2) can reveal the shared prime factor.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=4712401139916324197463577994409472335085326807548200171055544356374466169605754904431374927687932844845336303429759309028438846925997725007196670418275803, n2=7021751681354724785338252981968342029515080817018229161722818294944812859596860289421556580058638563852865392178753470870968499636104957750005714982251017, e=1155464652474737721100294710982594581740744116817794578290784982155087295633066402205873278963008261401489285095665238900365716523807483281719184262257123
